title: Scaling and Expanding the Use of Registered Apprenticeships in Industries and the Federal Government and Promoting Labor-Management Forums

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs federal agencies to expand and promote Registered Apprenticeship programs to create more equitable and accessible pathways for workforce development and Federal employment. It also reestablishes Labor-Management Forums across the executive branch to foster cooperative labor relations and improve agency effectiveness.
potential_concerns: Expanding apprenticeship requirements in federal grants and contracts may increase compliance burdens and costs for contractors and grantees, potentially disadvantaging small businesses and non-union employers.
Focusing hiring and career advancement on Registered Apprenticeships might disadvantage workers who do not participate in such programs or who come from non-traditional backgrounds.
Implementation depends on agency coordination and sufficient appropriations, so resource constraints or uneven adoption could limit effectiveness.
Reestablishing Labor-Management Forums may create tensions in agencies where labor-management relations are contentious or where unions have limited presence.
The orderâ€™s emphasis on apprenticeship and apprenticeship-aligned hiring might inadvertently reduce flexibility in agency hiring practices or slow recruitment in urgent positions.
